Completion Time Minimization of
Fog-RAN-Assisted Federated Learning With Rate-Splitting Transmission

Abstract

This work studies federated learning (FL) over a fog radio access network, in which multiple internet-of-things (IoT) devices cooperatively learn a shared machine learning model by communicating with a cloud server (CS) through distributed access points (APs). Under the assumption that the fronthaul links connecting APs to CS have finite capacity, a rate-splitting transmission at IoT devices (IDs) is proposed which enables hybrid edge and cloud decoding of split uplink messages. The problem of completion time minimization for FL is tackled by optimizing the rate-splitting transmission and fronthaul quantization strategies along with training hyperparameters such as precision and iteration numbers. Numerical results show that the proposed rate-splitting transmission achieves notable gains over benchmark schemes which rely solely on edge or cloud decoding.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, Fog-RAN, rate splitting, hybrid decoding, completion time minimization.

I Introduction

To alleviate the constraints on privacy and communication resources, centralized machine learning algorithms are envisioned to be replaced with distributed learning frameworks, in which distributed internet-of-things (IoT) devices collaboratively train a shared machine learning model while communicating with a cloud server (CS) [1]. In federated learning (FL), which is one of the most emerging distributed learning frameworks, IoT devices (IDs) upload locally trained models to CS [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. Accordingly, we can protect the privacy of local dataset and save the spectrum resource. To avoid long latency required for exchange of local and global model updates between IDs and CS, edge learning has been actively studied, which enjoys low latency by bringing the decision-making tasks closer to IDs [7]. However, proximate edge servers should perform partial model aggregation with limited computing powers. In this work, we focus on the cloud-based FL at CS, which cooperates with a wider range of IDs and has more access to data. To alleviate the communication bottleneck, we address the signal processing design of IDs, distributed access points (APs), and CS for low-latency transmission on wireless and fronthaul links.

In [4], wireless communication for FL was studied under a single-cell scenario, in which IDs communicate with a single AP directly connected to a CS. More complicated scenarios with multiple APs were discussed in [3, 5]. The problems of minimizing the energy consumption at IDs were tackled in [4, 3], while the completion time minimization for FL was addressed in [5]. For the transmission over wireless channel, frequency division multiple access (FDMA) was assumed in [4], and non-orthogonal transmission across IDs was considered in [3, 5]. Regarding the fronthauling strategy, [3] assumed that the fronthaul links can carry the uplink received signals of APs to the CS without distortion and latency. This assumption can be made possible only when the fronthaul links have sufficiently large capacity compared to the uplink bandwidth. The work in [5] addressed a more challenging and realistic case, where the capacity of fronthaul links is limited. The edge decoding strategy is considered, whereby each AP decodes the messages sent by the associated IDs and transmits the decoded information on fronthaul. However, when the fronthaul links have sufficient capacity, cloud decoding would be a more efficient strategy, in which the fronthaul links carry quantized and compressed version of the uplink signals, and a joint cloud decoding at CS is followed.

In this work, we study FL over a fog radio access network (RAN), in which multiple IDs cooperate to handle a machine learning task by repeatedly uploading locally updated models to a CS through distributed APs. We aim at achieving the advantages of both the edge and cloud decoding strategies by adopting rate-splitting transmission at IDs. The effectiveness of the rate-splitting approach has been reported in [8, 9, 10, 11] in terms of overcoming the impairments caused by channel state information (CSI) uncertainty and generalizing existing multiple access techniques. The degrees-of-freedom (DoFs) region of the rate-splitting scheme was analyzed in [8] for multi-cell multiple-input single-output (MISO) interference channel (IC) with arbitrary CSI quality. A generalized linearly precoded multiple access scheme referred to as rate-splitting multiple access was proposed in [9] which subsumes conventional space-division and non-orthogonal multiple access schemes as special cases. In [10], the advantages of the rate-splitting transmission were studied for MISO broadcast channel (BC) with heterogeneous CSI qualities among users in terms of DoFs and average sum-rate. We refer to [11] for a comprehensive overview of rate-splitting techniques including appealing applications and standardization issues.

In this work, we study an application of the rate-splitting transmission for fog-RAN-assisted FL. In the proposed rate-splitting scheme, each ID splits its message into two submessages, which are encoded to independent data streams, and the two encoded signals are delivered to CS by means of superposition coding and edge and cloud decoding strategies. We minimize the competition time of the FL algorithm. Our design includes the joint optimization of the rate-splitting transmission and fronthaul quantization strategies along with hyperparameters of training algorithms, in particular, the algorithm precision and iteration numbers satisfying a target learning performance. Numerical results validate the advantages of the proposed FL system in terms of completion time.

II Federated Learning System Over Fog-RAN

We consider an FL system in a fog network, in which a CS and NIsubscript𝑁𝐼N_{I} IDs collaboratively learn a machine learning model through NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} APs. The IDs and APs, each equipped with MIsubscript𝑀𝐼M_{I} and MAsubscript𝑀𝐴M_{A} antennas, communicate on wireless access channels. The APs are connected to the CS via orthogonal digital fronthaul links each of capacity CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} bits per second (bps). We define the index sets 𝒩I≜{1,…,NI}≜subscript𝒩𝐼1…subscript𝑁𝐼\mathcal{N}_{I}\triangleq\{1,\ldots,N_{I}\} and 𝒩A≜{1,…,NA}≜subscript𝒩𝐴1…subscript𝑁𝐴\mathcal{N}_{A}\triangleq\{1,\ldots,N_{A}\}. The goal of FL is to find a parameter vector 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} of a machine learning model with distributed datasets at IDs. Such a problem can be formulated as the minimization of a global loss function fL​(𝐰)=(1/∑l∈𝒩IDl)​∑k∈𝒩IDk​fL,k​(𝐰)subscript𝑓𝐿𝐰1subscript𝑙subscript𝒩𝐼subscript𝐷𝑙subscript𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑓𝐿𝑘𝐰f_{L}(\mathbf{w})=(1/\sum_{l\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}D_{l})\sum_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}D_{k}f_{L,k}(\mathbf{w}) where fL,k​(𝐰)subscript𝑓𝐿𝑘𝐰f_{L,k}(\mathbf{w}) represents the local loss function computed at ID k𝑘k using Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} data samples.

Fig. 1 illustrates the overall procedure of the FL containing nGsubscript𝑛𝐺n_{G} global iterations. Each global iteration consists of four steps: local computation at IDs; local model upload from IDs to CS through APs; model aggregation at CS; and global model broadcast from CS to IDs through APs. Individual IDs update their local parameter vectors using, e.g., the gradient descent (GD) method, with nLsubscript𝑛𝐿n_{L} local iterations. Updated models are then sent to distributed APs through wireless uplink channels, and each AP conveys received local models to the CS via capacity-constrained fronthaul links. After aggregating local models, the CS broadcasts a global model to all IDs. These are repeated for nGsubscript𝑛𝐺n_{G} global iterations.

The iteration numbers nGsubscript𝑛𝐺n_{G} and nLsubscript𝑛𝐿n_{L} depend on the target accuracy levels and the adopted FL algorithm. According to the analysis in [4], these are lower-bounded as

nLsubscript𝑛𝐿\displaystyle n_{L} ≥2(2−β​δ)​δ​α​log2⁡1ηL,absent22𝛽𝛿𝛿𝛼subscript21subscript𝜂𝐿\displaystyle\geq\frac{2}{(2-\beta\delta)\delta\alpha}\log_{2}\frac{1}{\eta_{L}}, (1)
nGsubscript𝑛𝐺\displaystyle n_{G} ≥2​β2α2​ξ​(1−ηL)​ln⁡1ηG,absent2superscript𝛽2superscript𝛼2𝜉1subscript𝜂𝐿1subscript𝜂𝐺\displaystyle\geq\frac{2\beta^{2}}{\alpha^{2}\xi(1-\eta_{L})}\ln\frac{1}{\eta_{G}}, (2)

where ηLsubscript𝜂𝐿\eta_{L} and ηGsubscript𝜂𝐺\eta_{G} respectively indicate the target accuracy levels for local and global optimization problems, and δ𝛿\delta denotes the learning rate. Constants α𝛼\alpha, β𝛽\beta, and ξ∈(0,α/β]𝜉0𝛼𝛽\xi\in(0,\alpha/\beta] are determined by the properties of the local training problem. Following [4, 6], we set α=2𝛼2\alpha=2, β=4𝛽4\beta=4, δ=1/4𝛿14\delta=1/4, and ξ=1/10𝜉110\xi=1/10, but the optimization algorithm proposed in this work can be applied for arbitrary values. The global accuracy target ηGsubscript𝜂𝐺\eta_{G} is related to the number of the global FL iterations nGsubscript𝑛𝐺n_{G}, and thus it can be fixed in advance. On the contrary, the local accuracy ηLsubscript𝜂𝐿\eta_{L} affects both the global and local iterations and invokes a nontrivial tradeoff. Reducing the local accuracy target ηLsubscript𝜂𝐿\eta_{L}, which imposes a smaller deviation from optimal solutions, requires a more local iterations nLsubscript𝑛𝐿n_{L}, but at the same time, can reduce the global FL repetitions nGsubscript𝑛𝐺n_{G}. Thus, we need to carefully design nLsubscript𝑛𝐿n_{L} along with the transmission strategy over wireless and fronthaul access links.

Thanks to the powerful computing resources of CS and higher transmission power of APs, the latency of the model aggregation and global model broadcast steps is negligible compared to that of the operations of IDs [4, 5, 6]. Thus, we can model the completion time τtotalsubscript𝜏total\tau_{\text{total}} as

τtotal=nG​(τC+τW+τF),subscript𝜏totalsubscript𝑛𝐺subscript𝜏𝐶subscript𝜏𝑊subscript𝜏𝐹\displaystyle\tau_{\text{total}}=n_{G}\left(\tau_{C}+\tau_{W}+\tau_{F}\right), (3)

where τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} is the local computation time and τWsubscript𝜏𝑊\tau_{W} and τFsubscript𝜏𝐹\tau_{F} respectively denote the latency associated with wireless and fronthaul access of the local model upload step. Let cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} be the local computing capacity of ID k𝑘k in CPU cycles per second. It is assumed that nCsubscript𝑛𝐶n_{C} CPU cycles are required for processing one data sample. Then, the local computation time at ID k𝑘k is given as nL​nC​Dk/cksubscript𝑛𝐿subscript𝑛𝐶subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘n_{L}n_{C}D_{k}/c_{k}. The overall computation time τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} is thus dominated by the worst-case ID as

τC=maxk∈𝒩I⁡nL​nC​Dkck.subscript𝜏𝐶subscript𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼subscript𝑛𝐿subscript𝑛𝐶subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘\displaystyle\tau_{C}=\max_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}\,\frac{n_{L}n_{C}D_{k}}{c_{k}}. (4)

We express the received signal vector 𝐲i∈ℂMAsubscript𝐲𝑖superscriptℂsubscript𝑀𝐴\mathbf{y}_{i}\in\mathbb{C}^{{M_{A}}} of AP i𝑖i on the wireless uplink channel of bandwidth B𝐵B Hz as

where 𝐇i,k∈ℂMA×MIsubscript𝐇𝑖𝑘superscriptℂsubscript𝑀𝐴subscript𝑀𝐼\mathbf{H}_{i,k}\in\mathbb{C}^{{M_{A}\times M_{I}}} denotes the channel matrix from ID k𝑘k to AP i𝑖i, 𝐱k∈ℂMIsubscript𝐱𝑘superscriptℂsubscript𝑀𝐼\mathbf{x}_{k}\in\mathbb{C}^{{M_{I}}} represents the transmitted signal of ID k𝑘k encoding its local model parameter, and 𝐳i∼𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,σz2​𝐈)similar-tosubscript𝐳𝑖𝒞𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑧2𝐈\mathbf{z}_{i}\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\sigma_{z}^{2}\mathbf{I}) is the noise at AP i𝑖i. All IDs are subject to the transmit power constraint 𝔼​[‖𝐱k‖2]≤Ptx𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑘2subscript𝑃tx\mathbb{E}\left[||\mathbf{x}_{k}||^{2}\right]\leq P_{\text{tx}}. We assign a serving AP ik∈𝒩Asubscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝒩𝐴i_{k}\in\mathcal{N}_{A} for ID k𝑘k to process the signal 𝐱ksubscript𝐱𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k}. For given i1,i2,…,iNIsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑖2…subscript𝑖subscript𝑁𝐼i_{1},i_{2},\ldots,i_{N_{I}}, we define the set 𝒩I,i⊆𝒩Isubscript𝒩𝐼𝑖subscript𝒩𝐼\mathcal{N}_{I,i}\subseteq\mathcal{N}_{I} of IDs served by AP i𝑖i, i.e.,

Accordingly, the edge-decoding signals 𝐬E,ksubscript𝐬𝐸𝑘\mathbf{s}_{E,k} of the IDs k∈𝒩I,i𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼𝑖k\in\mathcal{N}_{I,i} are decoded by EN i𝑖i and forwarded to the CS. In this work, we assume that the the AP-ID association 𝒩I,isubscript𝒩𝐼𝑖\mathcal{N}_{I,i} is arbitrarily predetermined and leave the optimization of those variables for future work.

III Rate-Splitting Transmission of Local Models

This section discusses the process of transmitting the locally updated models at IDs to the CS through distributed APs. One straightforward approach is a hard selection of decoding nodes for individual IDs. Each ID k𝑘k encodes the parameter vector of its local model into a single data message that can be decoded either by the serving AP iksubscript𝑖𝑘i_{k} (i.e., edge decoding) or the CS (i.e., cloud decoding). If the capacity CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} of fronthaul links is sufficiently large, it is desirable to select cloud decoding whereby the CS utilizes the uplink received signals of all the connected APs for centralized interference management. However, if the fronthaul capacity CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} is limited, the uplink signals reported to CS via fronthaul may contain quantization distortion noise of significant power. For this reason, for small CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F}, it is better to perform local edge decoding at APs avoiding the quantization distortion, even at the cost of the degradation by interference signals [12]. This observation invokes the combinatorial optimization of selecting one of the edge decoding and cloud decoding strategies for every ID, requiring an exhaustive search over 2NIsuperscript2subscript𝑁𝐼2^{N_{I}} possible cases.

To achieve the advantages of both decoding strategies avoiding a complicated search, we adopt the rate-splitting transmission [8, 10] which softly combines these two extreme decoding policies. Such a hybrid design facilitates an optimized APs-CS coordination for the successful decoding of local machine learning models, thereby improving the quality of the model aggregation at the CS. This approach is particularly beneficial for finite CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} that suffer from the nontrivial tradeoff between fronthaul overhead and centralized interference management. The local model of ID k𝑘k is assumed to be represented in dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} bits. Unlike the straightforward approach described above, ID k𝑘k divides the dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} bits into two bit strings of size dE,ksubscript𝑑𝐸𝑘d_{E,k} and dC,ksubscript𝑑𝐶𝑘d_{C,k} bits, which satisfy

dE,k+dC,k=dk,dE,k∈[0,dk].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝐸𝑘subscript𝑑𝐶𝑘subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑑𝐸𝑘0subscript𝑑𝑘\displaystyle d_{E,k}+d_{C,k}=d_{k},\,\,d_{E,k}\in[0,d_{k}]. (7)

These bit strings are separately encoded to data signals 𝐬E,k∈ℂMIsubscript𝐬𝐸𝑘superscriptℂsubscript𝑀𝐼\mathbf{s}_{E,k}\in\mathbb{C}^{{M_{I}}} and 𝐬C,k∈ℂMIsubscript𝐬𝐶𝑘superscriptℂsubscript𝑀𝐼\mathbf{s}_{C,k}\in\mathbb{C}^{{M_{I}}} which are distributed as 𝐬E,k∼𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,𝐐E,k)similar-tosubscript𝐬𝐸𝑘𝒞𝒩0subscript𝐐𝐸𝑘\mathbf{s}_{E,k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{Q}_{E,k}) and 𝐬C,k∼𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,𝐐C,k)similar-tosubscript𝐬𝐶𝑘𝒞𝒩0subscript𝐐𝐶𝑘\mathbf{s}_{C,k}\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{Q}_{C,k}), respectively, under Gaussian channel codebooks. The purpose of the described message splitting and independent encoding is to incorporate both the edge and cloud decoding approaches in such a way that one signal 𝐬E,ksubscript𝐬𝐸𝑘\mathbf{s}_{E,k} is decoded by the associated AP iksubscript𝑖𝑘i_{k} based on the local uplink signal 𝐲iksubscript𝐲subscript𝑖𝑘\mathbf{y}_{i_{k}}, and the other signal 𝐬C,ksubscript𝐬𝐶𝑘\mathbf{s}_{C,k} is decoded by the CS based on quantized signals received from all APs on fronthaul, which will be detailed in this section. Transmit covariances 𝐐E,k⪰𝟎succeeds-or-equalssubscript𝐐𝐸𝑘0\mathbf{Q}_{E,k}\succeq\mathbf{0} and 𝐐C,k⪰𝟎succeeds-or-equalssubscript𝐐𝐶𝑘0\mathbf{Q}_{C,k}\succeq\mathbf{0} are optimized along with the bit splitting variables dE,ksubscript𝑑𝐸𝑘d_{E,k} and dC,ksubscript𝑑𝐶𝑘d_{C,k}. Such an optimization policy can achieve performance at least those of edge decoding and cloud decoding schemes. ID k𝑘k transmits a superposition of the two signals 𝐬E,ksubscript𝐬𝐸𝑘\mathbf{s}_{E,k} and 𝐬C,ksubscript𝐬𝐶𝑘\mathbf{s}_{C,k}, i.e.,

𝐱k=𝐬E,k+𝐬C,k.subscript𝐱𝑘subscript𝐬𝐸𝑘subscript𝐬𝐶𝑘\displaystyle\mathbf{x}_{k}=\mathbf{s}_{E,k}+\mathbf{s}_{C,k}. (8)

With (8), the power constraint at ID k𝑘k can be rewritten as tr​(𝐐E,k)+tr​(𝐐C,k)≤Ptxtrsubscript𝐐𝐸𝑘trsubscript𝐐𝐶𝑘subscript𝑃tx\text{tr}\left(\mathbf{Q}_{E,k}\right)+\text{tr}\left(\mathbf{Q}_{C,k}\right)\leq P_{\text{tx}}.

AP i𝑖i decodes the edge-decoding signals {𝐬E,k}k∈𝒩I,isubscriptsubscript𝐬𝐸𝑘𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼𝑖\{\mathbf{s}_{E,k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I,i}} of the assigned IDs 𝒩I,isubscript𝒩𝐼𝑖\mathcal{N}_{I,i} using its uplink received signal 𝐲isubscript𝐲𝑖\mathbf{y}_{i}. We assume independent decoding of those signals to prevent decoding latency. Then, the data rate RE,ksubscript𝑅𝐸𝑘R_{E,k} of each signal 𝐬E,ksubscript𝐬𝐸𝑘\mathbf{s}_{E,k}, k∈𝒩I,i𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼𝑖k\in\mathcal{N}_{I,i}, is given by RE,k=B​fE,k​(𝐐)subscript𝑅𝐸𝑘𝐵subscript𝑓𝐸𝑘𝐐R_{E,k}=Bf_{E,k}(\mathbf{Q}) [13], where the function fE,kik​(𝐐)superscriptsubscript𝑓𝐸𝑘subscript𝑖𝑘𝐐f_{E,k}^{{i_{k}}}(\mathbf{Q}) measures the mutual information I​(𝐬E,k;𝐲i)𝐼subscript𝐬𝐸𝑘subscript𝐲𝑖I(\mathbf{s}_{E,k};\mathbf{y}_{i}) and can be computed as

fE,kik​(𝐐)=log2​det(𝐈+𝐖E,k−1​𝐇ik,k​𝐐E,k​𝐇ik,kH),superscriptsubscript𝑓𝐸𝑘subscript𝑖𝑘𝐐subscript2𝐈superscriptsubscript𝐖𝐸𝑘1subscript𝐇subscript𝑖𝑘𝑘subscript𝐐𝐸𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐇subscript𝑖𝑘𝑘𝐻\displaystyle f_{E,k}^{{i_{k}}}(\mathbf{Q})=\log_{2}\det\left(\mathbf{I}+\mathbf{W}_{E,k}^{-1}\mathbf{H}_{{i_{k}},k}\mathbf{Q}_{E,k}\mathbf{H}_{{i_{k}},k}^{H}\right), (9)

with 𝐐≜[[𝐐E,k]k∈𝒩I​[𝐐C,k]k∈𝒩I]≜𝐐delimited-[]subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐐𝐸𝑘𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐐𝐶𝑘𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼\mathbf{Q}\triangleq[[\mathbf{Q}_{E,k}]_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}\,[\mathbf{Q}_{C,k}]_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}] and 𝐖E,k≜∑l∈𝒩I∖{k}𝐇ik,l​𝐐E,l​𝐇ik,lH+∑l∈𝒩I𝐇ik,l​𝐐C,l​𝐇ik,lH+σz2​𝐈≜subscript𝐖𝐸𝑘subscript𝑙subscript𝒩𝐼𝑘subscript𝐇subscript𝑖𝑘𝑙subscript𝐐𝐸𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐇subscript𝑖𝑘𝑙𝐻subscript𝑙subscript𝒩𝐼subscript𝐇subscript𝑖𝑘𝑙subscript𝐐𝐶𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐇subscript𝑖𝑘𝑙𝐻superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑧2𝐈\mathbf{W}_{E,k}\triangleq\sum\nolimits_{l\in\mathcal{N}_{I}\setminus\{k\}}\mathbf{H}_{{i_{k}},l}\mathbf{Q}_{E,l}\mathbf{H}_{{i_{k}},l}^{H}+\sum\nolimits_{l\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}\mathbf{H}_{{i_{k}},l}\mathbf{Q}_{C,l}\mathbf{H}_{{i_{k}},l}^{H}+\sigma_{z}^{2}\mathbf{I}. Here we use the notation [𝐀l]l∈𝒩subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐀𝑙𝑙𝒩[\mathbf{A}_{l}]_{l\in\mathcal{N}} to denote the matrix obtained by horizontally concatenating the matrices 𝐀lsubscript𝐀𝑙\mathbf{A}_{l}, l∈𝒩𝑙𝒩l\in\mathcal{N}. After the edge decoding, AP i𝑖i subtracts the impact of the decoded signals {𝐬E,k}k∈𝒩I,isubscriptsubscript𝐬𝐸𝑘𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼𝑖\{\mathbf{s}_{E,k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I,i}} from the received signal 𝐲isubscript𝐲𝑖\mathbf{y}_{i} in (5). The resulting output 𝐲~i≜𝐲i−∑l∈𝒩I,i𝐇i,l​𝐬E,l≜subscript~𝐲𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖subscript𝑙subscript𝒩𝐼𝑖subscript𝐇𝑖𝑙subscript𝐬𝐸𝑙\tilde{\mathbf{y}}_{i}\triangleq\mathbf{y}_{i}-\sum\nolimits_{l\in\mathcal{N}_{I,i}}\mathbf{H}_{i,l}\mathbf{s}_{E,l} is obtained as

𝐲~i=∑l∈𝒩I∖𝒩I,i𝐇i,l​𝐬E,l+∑l∈𝒩I𝐇i,l​𝐬C,l+𝐳i.subscript~𝐲𝑖subscript𝑙subscript𝒩𝐼subscript𝒩𝐼𝑖subscript𝐇𝑖𝑙subscript𝐬𝐸𝑙subscript𝑙subscript𝒩𝐼subscript𝐇𝑖𝑙subscript𝐬𝐶𝑙subscript𝐳𝑖\displaystyle\tilde{\mathbf{y}}_{i}=\sum\nolimits_{l\in\mathcal{N}_{I}\setminus\mathcal{N}_{I,i}}\mathbf{H}_{i,l}\mathbf{s}_{E,l}+\sum\nolimits_{l\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}\mathbf{H}_{i,l}\mathbf{s}_{C,l}+\mathbf{z}_{i}. (10)

Along with the edge-decoded signals {𝐬E,k}k∈𝒩I,isubscriptsubscript𝐬𝐸𝑘𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼𝑖\{\mathbf{s}_{E,k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I,i}}, the signal 𝐲~isubscript~𝐲𝑖\tilde{\mathbf{y}}_{i} is then transferred to the CS to perform the cloud decoding of {𝐬C,k}k∈𝒩Isubscriptsubscript𝐬𝐶𝑘𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼\{\mathbf{s}_{C,k}\}_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}. As the fronthaul link carrying the signal 𝐲~isubscript~𝐲𝑖\tilde{\mathbf{y}}_{i} has a finite capacity of CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} bps, the signal needs to be quantized and compressed to a bit stream prior to fronthauling.

Following the rate-distortion theory [13], the quantized version 𝐲^isubscript^𝐲𝑖\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{i} of 𝐲~isubscript~𝐲𝑖\tilde{\mathbf{y}}_{i}, that is obtained by decompressing the bit stream at the CS, can be modeled as

𝐲^i=𝐲~i+𝐪i,subscript^𝐲𝑖subscript~𝐲𝑖subscript𝐪𝑖\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{i}=\tilde{\mathbf{y}}_{i}+\mathbf{q}_{i}, (11)

where the quantization noise 𝐪isubscript𝐪𝑖\mathbf{q}_{i} is independent of 𝐲~isubscript~𝐲𝑖\tilde{\mathbf{y}}_{i} and distributed as 𝐪i∼𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,𝛀i)similar-tosubscript𝐪𝑖𝒞𝒩0subscript𝛀𝑖\mathbf{q}_{i}\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{\Omega}_{i}). For a given 𝛀isubscript𝛀𝑖\mathbf{\Omega}_{i}, the quantized signal 𝐲^isubscript^𝐲𝑖\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{i} can be represented by B​τW​gi​(𝐐,𝛀i)𝐵subscript𝜏𝑊subscript𝑔𝑖𝐐subscript𝛀𝑖B\tau_{W}g_{i}(\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{\Omega}_{i}) bits [14], which depends on the transmission time on the wireless uplink channel in (3). The function gi​(𝐐,𝛀i)subscript𝑔𝑖𝐐subscript𝛀𝑖g_{i}(\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{\Omega}_{i}) measuring the number of compression bits per symbol, i.e., the compression rate, is given as [13]

gi​(𝐐,𝛀i)=I​(𝐲~i;𝐲^i)=log2​det(𝐈+𝛀i−1​𝐖A,i),subscript𝑔𝑖𝐐subscript𝛀𝑖𝐼subscript~𝐲𝑖subscript^𝐲𝑖subscript2𝐈superscriptsubscript𝛀𝑖1subscript𝐖𝐴𝑖\displaystyle g_{i}(\mathbf{Q},\mathbf{\Omega}_{i})=I(\tilde{\mathbf{y}}_{i};\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{i})=\log_{2}\det\left(\mathbf{I}+\mathbf{\Omega}_{i}^{-1}\mathbf{W}_{A,i}\right), (12)

with 𝐖A,i≜σz2​𝐈+∑l∈𝒩I∖𝒩I,i𝐇i,l​𝐐E,l​𝐇i,lH+∑l∈𝒩I𝐇i,l​𝐐C,l​𝐇i,lH≜subscript𝐖𝐴𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑧2𝐈subscript𝑙subscript𝒩𝐼subscript𝒩𝐼𝑖subscript𝐇𝑖𝑙subscript𝐐𝐸𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐇𝑖𝑙𝐻subscript𝑙subscript𝒩𝐼subscript𝐇𝑖𝑙subscript𝐐𝐶𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐇𝑖𝑙𝐻\mathbf{W}_{A,i}\triangleq\sigma_{z}^{2}\mathbf{I}+\sum\nolimits_{l\in\mathcal{N}_{I}\setminus\mathcal{N}_{I,i}}\mathbf{H}_{i,l}\mathbf{Q}_{E,l}\mathbf{H}_{i,l}^{H}+\sum\nolimits_{l\in\mathcal{N}_{I}}\mathbf{H}_{i,l}\mathbf{Q}_{C,l}\mathbf{H}_{i,l}^{H}.

IV Completion Time Minimization

We address the joint optimization of the transmit covariance 𝐐𝐐\mathbf{Q} and the quantization noise covariance 𝛀𝛀\mathbf{\Omega}, along with the target local accuracy ηLsubscript𝜂𝐿\eta_{L} which affects both the numbers nLsubscript𝑛𝐿n_{L} and nGsubscript𝑛𝐺n_{G} of local and global iterations, aiming at minimizing the completion time τtotalsubscript𝜏total\tau_{\text{total}} in (3). We assume that the target global accuracy level ηGsubscript𝜂𝐺\eta_{G} is predetermined, since it is a requirement that should be satisfied by the proposed FL system. We can formulate the problem as

The constraints (17b), (17c), and (17d) impose that the computation time τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C}, the wireless transmission time τWsubscript𝜏𝑊\tau_{W}, and the fronthaul transmission time τFsubscript𝜏𝐹\tau_{F} are lower bounded by the right-hand sides (RHSs) of (4), (15), and (16), respectively. In order to make the constraint (16) more tractable, we have replaced the function gi​(𝐐,𝛀i)subscript𝑔𝑖𝐐subscript𝛀𝑖g_{i}(\mathbf{Q},\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{i}) in (16) with a variable RF,isubscript𝑅𝐹𝑖R_{F,i} adding a constraint RF,i≥gi​(𝐐,𝛀i)subscript𝑅𝐹𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖𝐐subscript𝛀𝑖R_{F,i}\geq g_{i}(\mathbf{Q},\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{i}) in (17g). In the constraints (17e) and (17f) on the data rates RE,ksubscript𝑅𝐸𝑘R_{E,k} and RC,ksubscript𝑅𝐶𝑘R_{C,k} of the edge-decoding and cloud-decoding signals, the RHSs represent the maximum achievable data rates explained in Sec. III. The constraints (17h) and (17i) on the numbers of local nLsubscript𝑛𝐿n_{L} and global iterations nGsubscript𝑛𝐺n_{G} come from (1) and (2). The constraint (17j) imposes the transmission power constraints at all IDs, and the last constraint (17k) rewrites (7).

To find an efficient solution of the non-convex problem (17), we propose an iterative algorithm, which repeatedly updates the optimization variables by solving the convex problems obtained by convexifying the non-convex functions. Although the problem (29) is still non-convex, we obtain a convex problem if the additional variables {𝝀,𝚪,𝚯,𝚺}𝝀𝚪𝚯𝚺\{\boldsymbol{\lambda},\boldsymbol{\Gamma},\boldsymbol{\Theta},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\} are fixed. Therefore, with a proper choice of initial variables {𝐐~,𝛀,𝐝,ηL,𝐧}~𝐐𝛀𝐝subscript𝜂𝐿𝐧\{\tilde{\mathbf{Q}},\boldsymbol{\Omega},\mathbf{d},\eta_{L},\mathbf{n}\}, a sequence of monotonically decreasing cost values can be obtained by alternately updating the variable sets {𝐐~,𝛀,𝐝,ηL,𝐧}~𝐐𝛀𝐝subscript𝜂𝐿𝐧\{\tilde{\mathbf{Q}},\boldsymbol{\Omega},\mathbf{d},\eta_{L},\mathbf{n}\} and {𝝀,𝚪,𝚯,𝚺}𝝀𝚪𝚯𝚺\{\boldsymbol{\lambda},\boldsymbol{\Gamma},\boldsymbol{\Theta},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\}. We summarize the detailed algorithm in Algorithm 1. Because the optimal completion time τtotalsubscript𝜏total\tau_{\text{total}} is not divergent, the solution of Algorithm 1 converges to a locally optimal point111We leave the development of an efficient algorithm that finds a global optimal solution of problem (17) as a future work. of the problem (29). In Step 6, ethsubscript𝑒the_{\text{th}} indicates the threshold value for judging the convergence in terms of cost function value, and tmaxsubscript𝑡t_{\max} is the maximum allowed number of iterations. After convergence, each transmit covariance matrix 𝐐m,ksubscript𝐐𝑚𝑘\mathbf{Q}_{m,k} is obtained as 𝐐m,k←𝐐~m,k​𝐐~m,kH←subscript𝐐𝑚𝑘subscript~𝐐𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝐐𝑚𝑘𝐻\mathbf{Q}_{m,k}\leftarrow\tilde{\mathbf{Q}}_{m,k}\tilde{\mathbf{Q}}_{m,k}^{H} for m∈{E,C}𝑚𝐸𝐶m\in\{E,C\}, k∈𝒩I𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}.

The complexity of Algorithm 1 is the product of the number of iterations and the complexity of each iteration, i.e., Steps 3, 4, and 5. The latter is dominated by the complexity required to solve the convex problem at Step 4, i.e., the convex problem obtained by fixing {𝚲,𝚪,𝚯,𝚺}𝚲𝚪𝚯𝚺\{\boldsymbol{\Lambda},\boldsymbol{\Gamma},\boldsymbol{\Theta},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\} in problem (29). It was shown in [17, p. 4] that the worst-case complexity of finding a solution of a generic convex optimization problem is given as 𝒪​(nv​(nv3+nc)​log⁡(1/ϵ))𝒪subscript𝑛𝑣superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑣3subscript𝑛𝑐1italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(n_{v}(n_{v}^{3}+n_{c})\log(1/\epsilon)). Here nvsubscript𝑛𝑣n_{v} indicates the number of optimization variables, ncsubscript𝑛𝑐n_{c} denotes the number of arithmetic operations required to compute the objective and constraint functions, and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon represents the desired error tolerance level. The numbers nvsubscript𝑛𝑣n_{v} and ncsubscript𝑛𝑐n_{c} for the convex problem of Step 4 are given as nv=𝒪​(max⁡{MI2​NI,MA2​NA})subscript𝑛𝑣𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑀𝐼2subscript𝑁𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑀𝐴2subscript𝑁𝐴n_{v}=\mathcal{O}(\max\{M_{I}^{2}N_{I},M_{A}^{2}N_{A}\}) and nc=𝒪​(MA2​NA2​MI2​NI)subscript𝑛𝑐𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑀𝐴2superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐴2superscriptsubscript𝑀𝐼2subscript𝑁𝐼n_{c}=\mathcal{O}(M_{A}^{2}N_{A}^{2}M_{I}^{2}N_{I}), respectively. The number of iterations required for convergence is determined by the convergence rate, but its analysis for general successive convex approximation algorithms is still an open problem and is left as a future work.

V Numerical Results

We evaluate the performance of the fog-RAN-assisted FL system which adopts the proposed optimized rate-splitting scheme and compare with the following schemes: Edge-decoding only (dE,k=dksubscript𝑑𝐸𝑘subscript𝑑𝑘d_{E,k}=d_{k}, ∀k∈𝒩Ifor-all𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼\forall k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}) and cloud-decoding only schemes (dE,k=0subscript𝑑𝐸𝑘0d_{E,k}=0, ∀k∈𝒩Ifor-all𝑘subscript𝒩𝐼\forall k\in\mathcal{N}_{I}). IDs and APs are randomly distributed within an area of radius 200 m while satisfying the minimum separation of 10 m. The Rayleigh fading model is adopted as 𝐇i,k=ρ0​(disti,k/dist0)−γ/2​𝐇~i,ksubscript𝐇𝑖𝑘subscript𝜌0superscriptsubscriptdist𝑖𝑘subscriptdist0𝛾2subscript~𝐇𝑖𝑘\mathbf{H}_{i,k}=\rho_{0}(\text{dist}_{i,k}/\text{dist}_{0})^{-\gamma/2}\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{i,k} where disti,ksubscriptdist𝑖𝑘\text{dist}_{i,k} is the distance between ID k𝑘k and AP i𝑖i, ρ0=10subscript𝜌010\rho_{0}=10 dB stands for the path-loss at reference distance dist0=50subscriptdist050\text{dist}_{0}=50 m, and the small-scale fading 𝐇~i,ksubscript~𝐇𝑖𝑘\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{i,k} is distributed as vec​(𝐇~i,k)∼𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,𝐈)similar-tovecsubscript~𝐇𝑖𝑘𝒞𝒩0𝐈\text{vec}(\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{i,k})\sim\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{I}). The parameters of local computing tasks are set to Dk=500subscript𝐷𝑘500D_{k}=500, dk=28⋅103subscript𝑑𝑘⋅28superscript103d_{k}=28\cdot 10^{3}, ck=3⋅109subscript𝑐𝑘⋅3superscript109c_{k}=3\cdot 10^{9}, and nC∈{200,2000}subscript𝑛𝐶2002000n_{C}\in\{200,2000\} [3, 4, 6]. We also fix Ptx/σz2=10subscript𝑃txsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑧210P_{\text{tx}}/\sigma_{z}^{2}=10 dB, B=20𝐵20B=20 MHz, (MI,MA)=(1,2)subscript𝑀𝐼subscript𝑀𝐴12({M_{I},M_{A}})=(1,2), and ηG=10−3subscript𝜂𝐺superscript103\eta_{G}=10^{-3} unless stated otherwise.

Fig. 2 depicts the average completion time 𝔼​[τtotal]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜏total\mathbb{E}[\tau_{\text{total}}] versus the fronthaul capacity CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} for NI=10subscript𝑁𝐼10N_{I}=10, NA∈{2,3}subscript𝑁𝐴23N_{A}\in\{2,3\}, and nC=200subscript𝑛𝐶200n_{C}=200. The performance of all schemes is improved with a larger CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} due to the savings in the fronthaul latency τFsubscript𝜏𝐹\tau_{F}. The cloud-decoding scheme gets more benefit than the edge-decoding scheme thanks to more pronounced impact of cooperative cloud detection. For all simulated scenarios, the rate-splitting transmission with the proposed optimization algorithm provides relevant gains compared to the baseline schemes. The gain over the cloud-decoding scheme is more significant for the case with less APs, in which the impact of cooperative cloud decoding would be marginal.

Fig. 3 plots the average optimized local accuracy level 𝔼​[ηL]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜂𝐿\mathbb{E}[\eta_{L}] with respect to the fronthaul capacity CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} for the same setup in Fig. 2. As CFsubscript𝐶𝐹C_{F} increases, the impact of the fronthaul latency τFsubscript𝜏𝐹\tau_{F} on the completion time (3) decreases. Thus, it is desirable to choose a larger local accuracy level ηLsubscript𝜂𝐿\eta_{L} to suppress the computation time τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C}. In a similar vein, the optimized local accuracy of the rate-splitting scheme is larger than those of the baseline schemes, since it requires shorter transmission times τWsubscript𝜏𝑊\tau_{W} and τFsubscript𝜏𝐹\tau_{F}, which lead to a larger dominance of the computation time τCsubscript𝜏𝐶\tau_{C} than the other schemes.

In Fig. 4, we plot the average completion time 𝔼​[τtotal]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜏total\mathbb{E}[\tau_{\text{total}}] versus the number NAsubscript𝑁𝐴N_{A} of APs for NI=7subscript𝑁𝐼7N_{I}=7, (MI,MA)=(2,2)subscript𝑀𝐼subscript𝑀𝐴22(M_{I},M_{A})=(2,2), nC=200subscript𝑛𝐶200n_{C}=200, CF=500subscript𝐶𝐹500C_{F}=500 Mbps, B=100𝐵100B=100 MHz, and Ptx/σz2∈{0,15}subscript𝑃txsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑧2015P_{\text{tx}}/\sigma_{z}^{2}\in\{0,15\} dB. The cloud-decoding strategy outperforms the edge-decoding scheme when there are many APs due to more effective interference management capability enabled by joint decoding at CS. However, if only a few APs are involved, the edge-decoding scheme shows lower latency, which means that the impact of quantization noise signals of the cloud-decoding scheme cannot be counter-balanced by the advantage of cooperative decoding among small number of APs.

VI Conclusion

We have studied a fog-RAN-assisted FL system with finite-capacity fronthaul links. To enable flexible hybrid edge and cloud decoding strategies, we have proposed a rate-splitting transmission scheme and have tackled the problem of minimizing the completion time of FL with a given target global accuracy requirement. Via numerical results, we have checked the performance gain of the proposed optimized rate-splitting scheme over benchmark schemes and observed the impacts of various system parameters on the performance gains and the optimized local accuracy level. Among interesting open problems, we mention the optimization of global accuracy level and identifying its relation to test accuracy in actual learning tasks.
